subtopics.title: Introduction to Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Introduction

In earlier classes, you learned about natural numbers, whole numbers, and integers. But sometimes, integers are not enough to express certain values. For example, when you share a chocolate bar equally among 3 friends, you get fractions like 1/3. These are not integers, but they are still numbers we use in daily life. Such numbers are called rational numbers. They help us represent parts of a whole, ratios, and values between integers.

subtopics.title: Definition of Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Definition

A rational number is any number that can be expressed in the form: p/q, where p and q are integers, and q ≠ 0.

Examples:

2/3, -7/4, 0, 5, -11/9 are all rational numbers.

subtopics.title: Properties of Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Closure Property

Rational numbers are closed under addition, subtraction, and multiplication.

Example: 2/3 + 5/6 = 9/6 = 3/2 (still rational).

Not closed under square root in general (e.g., √2 is not rational).

Commutative Property

a + b = b + a, a × b = b × a.

Example: 2/3 + 1/4 = 1/4 + 2/3.

Associative Property

Addition and multiplication are associative.

Example: (1/2 + 1/3) + 1/4 = 1/2 + (1/3 + 1/4).

Distributive Property

a × (b + c) = a × b + a × c.

subtopics.title: Representation on a Number Line
subtopics.content:
Number Line Representation

Rational numbers can be plotted on a number line like integers and fractions.

Example: 3/4 lies between 0 and 1.

Negative rationals are placed to the left of zero.

subtopics.title: Standard Form of Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Standard Form

A rational number is said to be in standard form when:

  • Denominator is positive.
  • Numerator and denominator have no common factors other than 1.

Example: -4/-6 = 2/3 (standard form).

subtopics.title: Comparison of Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Comparing Rational Numbers

To compare, bring them to a common denominator.

Example: Compare 2/3 and 3/5.

LCM of 3 and 5 = 15.

2/3 = 10/15, 3/5 = 9/15.

Thus, 2/3 > 3/5.

subtopics.title: Operations on Rational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Addition/Subtraction

Convert to common denominator, then add/subtract numerators.

Example: 5/12 - 7/18 = 15-14/36 = 1/36.

Multiplication

Multiply numerators and denominators.

Example: 2/3 × 5/7 = 10/21.

Division

Multiply by the reciprocal.

Example: 4/5 ÷ 2/3 = 4/5 × 3/2 = 12/10 = 6/5.

questions.question: Which of the following is a rational number?
questions.explanation: A rational number is any number that can be expressed as p/q where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0. –7/3 fits this definition.

questions.question: The standard form of –15/–35 is:
questions.explanation: To get the standard form, we simplify –15/–35 = 15/35 = 3/7. In standard form, the denominator must be positive.

questions.question: Which property is shown by 2/3 + 4/5 = 4/5 + 2/3?
questions.explanation: The commutative property states that the order of addition does not affect the result: a + b = b + a.

questions.question: The reciprocal of –7/9 is:
questions.explanation: The reciprocal of a fraction a/b is b/a. So the reciprocal of –7/9 is 9/–7 = –9/7.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a rational number?
questions.explanation: All the given options are rational numbers. 0/5 = 0, –11/7, 5 = 5/1, and 9/–3 = –3 are all rational numbers.

questions.question: The sum of 3/4 + 5/6 is:
questions.explanation: To add 3/4 + 5/6, we find the LCM of denominators (12). 3/4 = 9/12 and 5/6 = 10/12. So 9/12 + 10/12 = 19/12.

questions.question: On the number line, the rational number –5/8 lies between:
questions.explanation: Since –5/8 is negative but greater than –1 (because 5/8 < 1), it lies between –1 and 0 on the number line.

questions.question: Which is greater: 7/12 or 5/8?
questions.explanation: To compare, we convert to common denominator. LCM of 12 and 8 is 24. 7/12 = 14/24 and 5/8 = 15/24. Since 15/24 > 14/24, 5/8 is greater.
